awd_titl_txt: CCRI: Planning-C: Developing a Minecraft-based Testbed for Evaluating Human-AI Teaming Research
awd_abstract_narration:
Human AI Teaming (HAT) is an emerging and rapidly evolving field where physical and virtual spaces require rapid strategic and tactical decision-making. In the context of national security, it is imperative to develop tools that can accelerate what is known as the observation to action loop, enabling decision makers to take swift and effective action that can reduce the impacts of our adversarial threats. It is common for teams to operate in dynamic and uncertain environments and they will require not only cooperation between human and artificial agents, but the use of artificial intelligence (AI) to help structure those teams, create plans of actions, execute those plans, and adapt plans as the environment and goals change. This integration between human and artificial agents can be used to enhance the speed and accuracy of human decision makers; automate the generation, evaluation, and execution of mission plans; and improve training effectiveness. 

This CISE Computing Research Infrastructure (CCRI) planning grant will undertake an exhaustive community-centric requirements gathering, testing and finalization process that would result in a comprehensive set of features necessary to build a software suite comprising of tools that would improve the effectiveness of human AI teams. Specifically, the proposed software testbed would be flexible and customizable to meet the needs of a broad community of AI researchers and helps them accelerate the development of AI agents that are designed to work in Human AI teams. By organizing the AI community into multiple working groups and disseminating the results via a workshop, the project aims to develop the requirements for modifying the popular Minecraft gaming platform including the data engineering, testing and evaluation requirements for tools that would achieve the desired goals within the HAT community of researchers. The team builds upon prior success in using Minecraft for conducting HAT experiments in Urban Search and Rescue (USR) based settings and broaden its use among AI researchers who would be interested in developing and testing HAT experiments. The resulting community feedback would be integrated into a CCRI full proposal that aims to build the software suite based on the requirements arising from the activities conducted via the planning grant.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
Human-AI Teaming (HAT) is an emerging and rapidly evolving field where physical and virtual spaces require rapid strategic and tactical decision-making. This CCRI planning project undertook an exhaustive community-centric requirements gathering, testing, and finalization process that would result in a comprehensive set of features necessary to build a software suite comprised of tools that would improve the effectiveness of human-AI teams. Throughout this project, the research team organized four working group meetings centered around 1) domain analysis and identification of communication requirements, 2) agent-human interaction design, 3) agent formalization for processing human input, and 4) developing software requirements for the testbed. A total of 20 experts participated in the working group discussions.

The research team worked on the following three objectives. The first was to develop a demonstration of the current Minecraft-based HAT testbed and prepare questions for panelists in the four working groups. The second was to identify domain experts for each of the working groups and conduct the working group meetings. The third was to perform a thematic analysis to codify the feedback obtained from the working groups and identify priority areas for future testbed development.

One major outcome from the thematic analysis is the identification of six priority areas towards the design of community research infrastructure for HAT: 1) testbed with customizable and/or reconfigurable scenarios, 2) testbed scalability, 3) support various application programming interfaces (APIs), 4) data recording methods, 5) artificial agent model, planning, and decision making, and 6) predefined measurement tools.

The knowledge gained in this planning project will be used for design of a future community-based HAT testbed, which holds the potential to build an active and interdisciplinary research community of computer scientists, software engineers, human factors experts, and roboticists. Many of the priorities and feedback identified in this project are applicable to a wide range of human-computer interaction and software engineering applications.

Another outcome of this project is a cohort of researchers interested in building the future community-based HAT testbed. Working group experts demonstrated great interest and enthusiasm to the HAT testbed, citing a lack of well-maintained, open-source, and user-friendly platforms to test hypotheses and evaluate algorithms.

The project involved four doctoral students, and one from an underrepresented group was partially supported by this project. Two students completed a research paper which is under review at the time of preparing this report.


Last Modified: 10/03/2023
Modified by: Wenlong Zhang
